item.title: Abelian Groups
item.description: Groups that commute. Definition A group \((G, \cdot)\) is abelian if the group operation is commutative. That is, if \(a \cdot b = b \cdot a\) for all \(a,b \in G\). Properties In an abelian group, we have that \((ab)^n = a^n b^n\) for all \(a,b \in G\) and \(n \in \Z\). Examples The set of integers under addition, \((\Z, +)\), is an abelian group. \(\Z\) is closed under addition, addition is associative and commutative, the identity element is \(0\), and if \(n \in \Z\), then its inverse is \(-n \in \Z\).

item.title: Cyclic Groups
item.description: Definitions A group \((G, \cdot)\) is a cyclic group if there exists an element \(a \in G\) such that every element of \(G\) can be written as \(a^k\) for some \(k \in \Z\). In this case, we write \(G = \langle a \rangle := \{a^k \mid k \in \Z \}\). Properties All cyclic groups are abelian. If \(G\) is an infinite cyclic group, then it is isomorphic to the integers, \((\Z, +)\), and if it is a finite cyclic group, then it is isomorphic to \(\Z_n\), the group of equivalence classes mod \(n\) where \(n = \vert G \vert\) is the order of the group.

item.title: Group Homomorphisms
item.description: Definitions Let \((G, \cdot)\) and \((H, \circ)\) be groups. A map \(\varphi: G \to H\) is called a group homomorphism if it preserves the group operation. That is, \(\varphi\) is a homomorphism if and only if for all \(a,b \in G\) we have \(\varphi(a \cdot b) = \varphi(a) \circ \varphi(b)\). If a homomorphism \(\varphi\) is called a monomorphism if it is injective, an epimorphism if it is surjective, and an isomorphism if it is bijective.

item.title: Groups
item.description: The symmetries of something. Definitions A group \((G, \cdot)\) is a set \(G\) together with a binary operation \(\cdot: G \times G \to G\) such that The group operation is associative: \((ab)c = a(bc)\) for all \(a,b,c \in G\); \(G\) has an identity element: there exists \(e \in G\) such that \(ae = a = ea\) for all \(a \in G\); Every element is invertible: for all \(a \in G\), there exists a \(b \in G\) such that \(ab = e = ba\).

item.title: The General Linear Group
item.description: Definition The general linear group denoted \(GL_n(\F)\) is the group of \(n\)-by-\(n\) invertible matrices over the field \(\F\).

item.title: The Group of Integers
item.description: Definition The set of equivalence classes on \(\Z\) modulo \(n\) forms a finite group. Properties The group is cyclic generated by the equivalence classes of numbers relatively prime to \(n\), and abelian since addition of equivalence classes is commutative.

item.title: The Group of Units
item.description: Sometimes denoted \(\Z_n^\times\). Definition The group of units mod \(n\), denoted \(U(n)\), is a finite group formed by removing the non-invertible elements of \(\Z_n\) (which are equivalence classes) under multiplication. Properties The group of units is an abelian group since multiplcation of equivalence classes is commutative. The group of units mod \(n\) is not always cyclic in general, but if \(n\) is \(2\), \(4\), \(p^k\), or \(2p^k\) for a prime \(p\) and natural number \(k\), then it is cyclic becuase the group has a generator.

item.title: The Klein Four-group
item.description: Definition The Klein four-group is a group that can be thought of in many ways, one of which is as the external direct product \(\Z_2 \times \Z_2\), and is typically denoted by \(V\). Properties The group is abelian. Every non-identity element has order \(2\). Examples The group can also be thought of as being given by the group presentation \(\langle a,b \mid a^2, b^2, (ab)^2 \rangle\). Alternatively, the group can be thought of as the subgroup of the general linear group \(GL_2(\R)\) given by \[V = \left\{ \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \right\}.

item.title: The Symmetric Group
item.description: Definitions The symmetric group on a set \(X\) is the group of bijections \[\Sym(X) = \{f: X \to X \mid f \text{ is bijective}\}\] together with the group operation of composition of mappings. The symmetric group on \(n\) symbols, denoted \(S_n\), is the symmetric group on the set \([n] := \{1, \dots, n\}\), the group of permutations. Properties The group \(S_n\) is not cyclic or abelian for \(n \geq 3\), and it is simple for \(n \geq 5\).

item.title: The Group of Integers
item.description: Definition The set of integers, \(\Z\), together with the operation addition forms an infinite group. Properties The group is cyclic generated by \(\pm 1\), and abelian since addition is commutative. Every subgroup of \(\Z\) has the form \(n\Z = \langle n \rangle = \{nz \mid z \in \Z\}\) for some \(n \in \Z\).
